summary: 02/09/1998: In Tbilisi, Georgia, a group of 10 to 15 assailants attacked the President Eduard Shevardnedze motorcade with automatic weapons and grenades, killing two people but leaving the president unharmed. According to the investigation by Georgian law enforcement, the group which carried out the attack was made up of Georgians and people from the North Caucasus. Ten perpetrators were arrested and charged following the investigation.
scite1: Suspects arrested in Shevardnadze assassination attempt, Associated Press  Worldstream, February 15, 1998.
scite2: American experts investigating terrorist act in Tbilisi, TASS, February 13, 1998.
scite3: Law-enforcement bodies identify assailants on President Shevardnadze, BBC Summary  of World Broadcasts, February 19, 1998.

summary: 02/20/1998: Heavily-armed gunmen seized four United Nations (UN) representatives, their Georgian driver and five other civilians after shelling the UN headquarters in the western town of Zugdidi, Georgia. The Zviadists led by Gocha Esebua, orchestrated the kidnapping in an attempt to negotiate the release of suspects being held for an assassination attempt on the Georgian President on February 9, 1998. The Georgian Government negotiated for the successful release of the kidnapped.
target1: Four United Nations Officials and their driver
scite1: Terrorists release all hostages in Georgia, Tass, February 25, 1998.
scite2: Kidnappers Behind Assassination Attempt, AAP Newsfeed, February 21, 1998.
scite3: Kidnappers of UN observers make demands, BBC Summary of World Broadcasts,  February 21, 1998.

summary: 04/02/1998: One hundred armed Abkhaz men entered the village of Primorskoye, Georgia and killed three men and captured nineteen others. The fate of the kidnap victims was unknown. They claimed that there intent was to purge the village of Georgian guerillas.
motive: To purge the village of Georgian guerillas.
scite1: "Abkhaz Militants Kill 3 Georgians in Gali District," Tbilisi Imprinda, April 2, 1998

summary: 04/05/1998: Five people were killed and six were injured when Sergo Meskhia and Bezhane Gvazare opened fire on a funeral procession in Zugdidi, Georgia.
target1: Civilians at a Georgian Funeral Procession
scite1: "Zugdidi Terrorist Attack Leaves 5 Dead, 6 Wounded," Tbilisi Kavkasia, April 6, 1998
scite2: Tengiz Pachkoria, "Criminals Who Fired at Funeral Procession Identified," Tass, April 6, 1998

summary: 07/12/1998: Georgian extremists were suspected of planting a mine that killed five Russian peacekeepers and wounded five others when their vehicle hit the mine in the town of Pichora, Abkhazia, Georgia.
scite1: Georgian Radio, Georgian Security Forces Blame Abkhaz, Russian Forces for Recent Blast, BBC Worldwide Monitoring, July 14, 1998.
scite2: Iya Barateli, Georgia: 5 Peacekeepers Killed in Abkhaz District Explosion,  ITAR-TASS World Service, July 12, 1998.
scite3: Abkhazians Blame Georgian Extremists for Killing Russians, Moscow NTV, July 13, 1998.

summary: 07/15/1998: The White Legion (Georgia) and the Forest Brothers were suspected of using a remote-controlled bomb to blow up a cart carrying villagers in the village of Sid, Georgia. Eight civilians were killed and two were wounded in this attack.
scite1: Death Toll from Blast in Abkhazia Increases to Eight, Interfax, July 15, 1998.
scite2: Georgian Security Disclaims Blame for Abkhazia Blasts, Tbilisi Kavkasia-Press, July 16, 1998.

summary: 07/22/1998: Eight unidentified Abkhaz militants went into the village of Orsantia, Georgia, and took an unspecified number of people hostage.
addnotes: One hostage was reported shot and killed. The fate of the other hostages was not reported.
scite1: Abkhaz Militants Reportedly Kidnap Georgian Civilians, Tbilisi Prime-News, July 22, 1998.
scite2: Georgian Hostage Reportedly Shot by Abkhaz Forces, Tbilisi Prime-News, July 23, 1998.
scite3: Prime News Agency, Georgian civilians taken hostage by Abkhaz side, BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, July 25, 1998.

location: This incident occurred outside of Gagiloni near the Georgian-Abkhaz border.
summary: 07/27/1998: An armored vehicle carrying Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) peacekeepers blew up after hitting an anti-tank mine outside of Gagiloni near the Georgian-Abkhaz border. Two peacekeepers were killed and three others were injured. It was uncertain if the mine was placed there to target the peacekeepers. No group or individual claimed credit for the attack.
scite1: Anzhela Kuchuberiva, Two CIS Peacekeepers Killed By Mine In Abkhazia, ITAR-TASS World Service, July 27, 1998.
scite2: More Abkhaz Forces Sent to Gali District Following Attacks, Tbilisi Prime-News, July 27, 1998.

summary: 08/11/1998: A group of ten unidentified Abkhaz militants crossed into Georgia and opened fire on civilians' houses in the city of Abastumani with grenade launchers. Although there was damage to several houses, no one was killed or injured in the attack.
scite1: Abkhaz Militants Open Fire on Georgian Civilians Houses, No Causalities, Kavkasia-Press News Agency, August 11, 1998.

summary: 08/24/1998: A bomb exploded in a regional administration building in Zugdidi, Georgia, killing two and injuring 30 other people. No one claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Regional administration building in Zugdidi, Georgia
scite1: Two killed in explosion in Georgian administration building, The Associated Press, August 24, 1998.
scite2: Georgian President Blames Blast on Gerorgias Enemies, Interfax Russian News, August 24, 1998.

location: This incident occurred on a road between posts 207 and 209 of the CIS Peacekeeping Force.
summary: 10/11/1998: Three Abkhazian policemen were killed when their police patrol was ambushed by unknown Georgian assailants. The attack occurred in Abkhazia, Georgia, on a road between posts 207 and 209 of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) Peacekeeping Force.
scite1: "Three Policemen Killed in Abkhaz Ambush, Interfax, October 12, 1998

summary: 10/29/1998: Eight unidentified gunmen killed one Abkhazian policeman and seriously wounded another in an attack on a police patrol car in Abkhazia, Georgia. The Abkhazian Interior Ministry placed responsibility for the act on "Georgia's authorities" and "power structures" who violated earlier cease-fire agreements in the security zone of the Gali District.
target1: Two Abkhazian Police officers in their patrol car in Georgia
scite1: Angela Kuchuberia, One Policeman Killed, another Wounded in Abkhazia Attack, TASS, October 29, 1998
scite2: "Georgia: Attack Kills Abkhaz Policeman, Wounds Another, ITAR-TASS, October 29, 1998.

summary: 03/13/1999: Slavik Vardania, an official from Abkhazia, was attacked by suspected Georgian rebels near the village of Mzuiri, Georgia. Vardania was traveling to Gali at the time of the attack.
propcomment: The victim's vehicle was damaged in this attack.
scite1: Abkhaz official wounded from ambush, Kavkasia-Press (Internet Version), March 13, 1999.

summary: 04/02/1999: Georgian guerrillas detonated an explosive device at an administration building of the Gali District of the republic of Abkhazia, Georgia, targeting the First Deputy Prime Minister, Konstantin Ozgan.
target1: First Deputy Prime Minister, Konstantin Ozgan
scite1: Abkhaz Group Protests Against Attack on Deputy Premier, Tbilisi Kavkasia-Press (Internet Version), April 7, 1999.

summary: 06/23/1999: Two people were killed and thirteen others were injured when a bus hit an anti-tank mine in the Gali district of Abkhazia, Georgia. The perpetrators of this incident were not known, but authorities called the attack a "deliberate terrorist act."
target1: Civilians in the Gali district of Abkhazia
scite1: "Crowded Bus Hits Anti-tank Mine in Georgia, 2 Dead," Xinhua News Agency, June 23, 1999.

summary: 07/09/1999: Georgian separatists kidnapped more than thirty officials and journalists from Azhara, Georgia and took them by helicopter to Chkharda. The kidnappers demanded a private meeting with Emzar Kvitsiani, the deputy representative of the Georgian president in the Kodori gorge, and Tengiz Gazdeliani, the Georgian Minister of Social Protection, Labour and Employment. The perpetrators eventually released seven women and an unknown number of journalists, but the full outcome of this incident was not reported.
motive: The kidnappers demanded a private meeting with Emzar Kvitsiani, the deputy representative of the Georgian president in the Kodori gorge, and Tengiz Gazdeliani, the Georgian Minister of Social Protection, Labour and Employment.
scite1: "Gunmen Kidnap Minister, Officials, Reporters in Abkhazia, Agence France Presse, July 9, 1999.
scite2: "Georgia: Kidnappers Release Hostage, Demand Meeting, Tbilisi Prime-News, July 9, 1999.

summary: 07/09/1999: A bomb exploded at the United Nations Observer Mission in Sukhumi, Georgia. No one was injured in the attack, which caused minor damaged. There was no claim of responsibility for this incident.
addnotes: Authorities detonated a second bomb nearby the first one.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1996-2001: A Chronology, Imprint Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.

summary: 10/13/1999: Unidentified masked gunmen took a group of seven United Nations military observers hostage in Azhara, in the breakaway Georgian province of Abkhazia. The gunmen demanded a 350,000 dollar ransom, but all of the hostages were freed three days later without the ransom being paid.
addnotes: The hostages included an interpreter, a German doctor, and five military observers from the Czech Republic, Greece, Sweden, Switzerland and Uruguay.
scite1: "Abkhaz Gunmen Demand Ransom for UN military observers, Agence France Presse, October 13, 1999.
scite2: "Georgian Rebels Seize U.N Hostages; 7 Monitors Captured in Separatist Region, The Patriot Ledger, October 13, 1999.
scite3: "Abkhaz Hostage Drama Ends as Last UN Observers Released, Agence France Presse, October 15, 1999.

summary: 11/24/1999: Unidentified attackers blew up armored vehicle, which belonged to Russian peacekeeping forces, near Otobaia, Georgia. Three people were killed and eight injured in the attack
target1: Russian Peacekeeping Forces armored vehicle near Otobaia, Georgia
scite1: Russian Armored Vehicle Blown up in Abkhazia; 3 Killed, Tbilisi Kavkasia-Press, November  25, 1999.
scite2: Three said killed in bomb attack on Russian armored vehicle in Abkhazia, Kavkasia-Press News Agency, November 25, 1999.
scite3: Abkhazia Takes Measures To Find Attackers of UNHCR Car, Moscow RIA, November 25, 1999.

summary: 01/25/2000: Unidentified persons opened fire on an Abkhaz militia post in Saberio, Gali District, killing two militiamen.
target1: An Abkhaz militia post in Saberio
scite1: Georgia: Two Abkhaz Militiamen Killed in Gali District, Kavkasia-Press (Internet Version), January 25, 2000.

summary: 05/24/2000: The car of Otar Turnanba, a staff member of the administration of Abkhazia's Ochamchira district in Georgia, came under attack by suspected Georgian radicals in Shesheleti, Abkhazia, Georgia. Three people were injured in the incident.
target1: Otar Turnanba, a Ochamchir District Administration Staff Member
weapdetail: A grenade launcher was used in the incident.
propcomment: The car was damaged in the attack.
scite1: "Abkhaz Administration Member Attacked by Grenade Fire, Interfax, May 25, 2000.

location: The incident took place near the village of Lata.
summary: 06/01/2000: A gang of unknown individuals kidnapped United Nations observers in the Kodor Gorge, near the village of Lata, Abkhazia, Georgia. The UN observers were released them four days later, on 06/05/2000, without demand of ransom. No casualties resulted from the incident.
target1: Kai Laursen and Thomas Rosenqvist, United Nations Military Observers
target2: John Woodword, a Member of Hullo Trust
addnotes: It is not certain why the gang kidnapped the observers. In the past, United Nations missionaries were kidnapped for ransom or political motives.
scite1: Elena Imedashvili, "UN missionaries kidnapped in Georgia", RIA Novosti, June 03, 2000.
scite2: "Five missing in Abkhazia, including two UN observers", Agence France Presse, June 02, 2000.
scite3: "All Kodori gorge hostages freed - presidential spokesman", Prime-News, June 06, 2000.

location: On the Kodori Highway in the center of Sukhumi, Abkhazia
summary: 8/15/2000: Zurab Achba, an advisor for the United Nations Human Rights Sukhumi office and a leader of the Abkhaz People's Forum, was shot and killed in the center of Sukhumi, Abkhazia, Georgia.  Achba was driving home when unidentified assailants opened fire on his car.  No group has claimed responsibility for the incident and the motive is unknown.  Achba was a former deputy of the Abkhaz Supreme Soviet.
target1: Zurab Achba, an ex-deputy of the Abkhaz Supreme Soviet, an advisor for the UN Human Rights office, and a leader of Abkhaz People's Forum
scite1: "UN special representative is shocked by the murder of Zurab Achba," Prime News, August 16, 2000.
scite2: "UN's Abkhaz "consultant" gunned down in Sukhumi," Prime News, August 16, 2000.
scite3: "Vladislav Ardzinba interrupted his holiday owing to assassination of former deputy," Black Sea Press, August 18, 2000.

summary: 10/20/2000: Unidentified people heavily wounded the former Georgian minister of fuel and energy, Davit Zubitashvili, as he passed the front door of his house last night in Tbilisi, Georgia. The Ministry of Internal Affairs believed that an attempt was made to abduct the former minister but after he put up resistance, he was shot point blank.
corp1: Former Georgian Minister of Fuel and Energy
addnotes: The Prosecutor-General's Office had long been investigating corruption in the fuel and energy sphere, including the period when Zubitashvili was minister. It was reported that the attack on Zubitashvili was possibly part of a feud within the energy mafia.
scite1: Former Georgian energy minister wounded in abduction attempt, Kavkasia-Press, October 21, 2000.

location: On the Tbilisi highway outside of Tbilisi
summary: 11/30/2000: Antonio Trevino and Francisco Rodriguez, two Spanish businessmen working on a Georgian-Spanish joint venture, were abducted on the Tbilisi highway outside of Tbilisi, Georgia.  They were in the company of the Tbilisi police chief when they were stopped by four armed men.  The assailants physically assaulted the police chief and threw him from the car, then kidnapped the two businessmen and their car.  The car was found abandoned near Naduknari village.   On December 8, 2001, the two men were released unharmed near the Chechnya border.  No group has been identified in relation to the abduction and it is unknown if a ransom was paid.
target1: Antonio Trevino and Francisco Rodriguez, two Spanish businessmen working on a Georgian-Spanish joint venture
addnotes: It is unclear whether the captives were voluntarily released or were rescued
scite1: "Update 1 - Two Spanish businessmen kidnapped in Georgia," Reuters, November 30, 2000.
scite2: Tengiz Pachkoria, "Georgia keeps up efforts for Spanish businessmen release," ITAR-TASS News Agency, December 2, 2000.
scite3: "Kidnapped Spanish businessmen released in Georgia," Reuters, December 8, 2001.

location: An area of the Kodor Gorge under Abkhazian control
summary: 12/10/2000: Two United Nations military observers, Lieutenant Colonel Zbigniew Blechacz from Poland and Captain Eustathios Kokkinitis from Greece, were abducted while patrolling an area of the Kodor Gorge, Abkhazia province, Georgia.  The captives were released in good health on December 13, 2000.  No ransom was paid for their release and the motive behind the abduction is uncertain.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
target1: Lieutenant Colonel Zbigniew Blechacz from Poland and Captain Eustathios Kokkinitis from Greece
weapdetail: No mention of weapons was made
addnotes: Sources state that the hostage-takers negotiated the release of the captives, but there is no mention of the conditions of release, other than that they did not include ransom.  In addition, the hostage-takers remained anonymous.
scite1: "U.N. workers kidnapped in Georgia's breakaway Abkhazia," Associated Press, December 10, 2000.
scite2: Tengiz Pachkoria," Kidnappers of UN officers still unidentified," ITAR-TASS News Agency, December 12, 2000.
scite3: "UN confirms release of hostages in Georgia," Agence France-Presse, December 13, 2000.

location: A road in a rural area outside of Gudava, in the Gali region of Abkhazia
summary: 07/22/2001: Four people, including two soldiers and two civilians, were killed when militants ambushed the truck they were traveling in near Gudava, Gali region, Abkhazia.  No group claimed responsibility for the incident.
target1: Two citizen traveling on the truck
motive: Although the specific motive was unknown, sources discussed other incidents of violence in the area, thought to be conducted by Georgian militants.
weapdetail: Two of the sources say the victims were ambushed and shot.  One source says that the truck they were traveling in was shelled, but this was not confirmed.
addnotes: Some authorities thought that the victims were caught in a shootout between rival gangs in the area.
scite1: "Four locals killed, Abkhazia blames Georgian guerrillas," Agence France-Presse, July 24, 2001.
scite2: Anzhela Kochuberia, "Four Abkhazians killed in terrorist act in Ghali region," ITAR-Tass, July 23, 2001.
scite3: "Four killed in Abkhaz attack," Interfax, July 23, 2001.

summary: 07/26/2001: Unidentified individuals shot and killed Giorgi Sanaia, a journalist for the Rustavi-2 television station, inside his home in Tbilisi, Georgia.  No group claimed responsibility.  Although some claimed the attack was politically motivated, the President of Georgia claimed he did not think this was the case.
corp1: Journalist with the television program Rustavi-2
motive: The specific motive for this incident was unknown.  Some suggested that the attack was politically motivated, but the President of Georgia claimed that this was not the case.
scite1: "Georgian TV journalist was shot dead - interior minister," Tbilisi Georgian TV, July 26, 2001.
scite2: "Georgian president confident truth will be established in TV killing," Tbilisi Georgian TV, July 27, 2001.

summary: 08/12/2001: A group of about 70 Jehovahs Witnesses were meeting in a private apartment when they were attacked by 15 assailants with sticks and metal rods in Rustavi, Georgia. The attackers set fire to religious literature and destroyed furniture and electrical equipment. Seven people were wounded in the incident.
target1: Gathering of Jehovah's Witnesses in Rustavi, Georgia
propcomment: The attackers set fire to religious literature and destroyed furniture and electrical equipment
scite1: Another attack on Jehovah's Witnesses reported, Prime-News, August 12, 2001.

summary: 08/20/2001: An attack was launched by an armed group of 30-40 ethnic Abkhaz, Armenians and Russians against residents of the Kodori Gorge in Georgia. One civilian was wounded and one attacker was reported killed and another wounded. The group seized horses and cattle before retreating into Abkhaz-controlled territory.
target1: Civilians and Property in the Kodori Gorge, Georgia
motive: The incident was cited by and official as an act of provocation aimed at dragging Georgia into fresh hostilities with Abkhaz separatists.
propcomment: The attackers seized cattle and horses in the incident.
scite1: Armed Abkhaz said attacking Kodori Gorge, Iprinda, August 20, 2001.

location: The incident took place in the Abkhazia region located in northwestern Georgia.
summary: 03/27/2002: An explosion aboard a commuter train killed one civilian and wounded fifteen more in the breakaway region of Abkhazia located in northwestern Georgia. The Abkhaz security services blamed the explosion on Georgian guerilla units, Forest Brothers and White Legion, and did not rule out the possibility that Georgian national secret services were involved. However Tamaz Nadareishvili, a member of the Georgian Security Council, denied the involvement of guerillas and security forces. Nadareishvili further stated that the bombing may have been a purely criminal act committed by Georgians, Abkhaz people or peacekeepers as part of a struggle to increase their spheres of influence. No official claim of responsibility was made.
target1: Indiscriminate civilians aboard a commuter train in Abkhazia, Georgia
target2: A commuter train in Abkhazia, Georgia
weapdetail: An unspecified explosive device was used in the incident.
propcomment: The explosion damaged the commuter train, however no official estimates as to the monetary value of the damage were released.
scite1: Georgian official denies involvement in Abkhaz bombings, Ekho Moskvy, March 27, 2002.
scite2: Commuter Train Blown Up In Abkhazia, 1 Killed, 15 Wounded, News Bulletin, March 27, 2002.
scite3: Georgian guerrilla leader denies responsibility for blasts in Abkhazia, Prime-News in Georgian, March 27, 2002.

summary: 06/19/2002: The director of the Georgian Argobusinessbank, a British national, was kidnapped in Tbilisi by criminals dressed in police uniforms.
scite1: British banker kidnapped in Georgia, Agence France Presse, June 19, 2002.
scite2: Georgian minister discusses progress of investigation into UK banker's abduction, Tbilisi Rustavi, June 25, 2002.
scite3: Georgia: Special services offer reward for information on kidnapped Briton, Interfax, June 20, 2002.

summary: 01/16/2003: The Georgian village of Chegali was the location of a failed assault on a Russian peacekeeper checkpoint guarding the Inguri hydroelectric power station by unknown assailants. The shootout resulted in several wounded on both sides but no reported deaths.
target1: Russian Peacekeeping Force, guarding the Inguri Hydroelectric station checkpoint
scite1: Russian peacekeepers reportedly attacked in Abkhazia, Iprinda, January 17, 2003.

summary: 01/31/2003: The Kavkasioni power transmission line was knocked out of service by unknown gunmen who damaged several electric insulators in the Tsalendzhikha district of Georgia.
scite1: Georgian power-supply system paralyzed by armed attack, Interfax, January 31, 2003.

summary: 10/03/2003: A grenade was thrown at a building housing the Georgian Revival Union, an opposition political party, in the town of Chkhorotsku, Georgia.  No casualties were reported, but the building suffered damage.  Although no claim of responsibility was made, representatives of the Georgian Revival Union blamed political opponents for the attack.
target1: Georgian Revival Union office in Chkhorotsku
propcomment: The blast blew out windows in the office and caused damage to the building.
addnotes: A similar attack was carried out in Tbilisi a month prior to this incident.
scite1: "Grenade Thrown at Georgian Revival Union's Office, No Casualties Reported," Moscow Interfax, October 4, 2003.
scite2: "World in Brief," The Washington Post, October 5, 2003.
scite3: "Attackers throw grenade at office of Georgian opposition party," Associated Press, October 4, 2003.

summary: 12/03/2003: An explosion with a charge equal to 300 grams of TNT was set off by unknown assailants between Rustavi-2 studios and the Georgian state TV building in the center of Georgian capital Tbilisi, shattering windows but resulting in no casualties.
target2: Georgian State Television building in Tbilisi
motive: The specific motive of the explosion was to disrupt the upcoming presidential elections.
addnotes: The blast took place sometime between 1755 and 1900 GMT, interrupting the evening live news broadcast near a wing of the state TV headquarters housing the state radio service. The claim of responsibility stated:" This is just the beginning. We are going to blow up the whole building."
scite1: Blast Near Georgian TV Office Should Not Cause Panic - Acting President, Interfax News Agency, December 4, 2003.
scite2: Explosion Rocks State TV Company Building, Canada News Wire, December 5, 2003.
scite3: Misha Dzhindzhikhashvili, U.S. Delegation Discusses Ways to Help New Georgian Authorities, Associated Press Worldstream, December 3, 2003.

summary: 12/19/2003: Unknown assailants fired automatic weapons at the home of the deputy chairman, Davit Japaridze, of the Tbilisi branch of the Union for Georgia's Democratic Revival political party in Tbilisi Georgia, injuring no one.
corp1: Union for Georgia's Democratic Revival Party
target1: Deputy chairman of the Tbilisi branch Davit Japaridze
scite1: Georgia: Shots Fired at House of Revival Party Tbilisi Branch Deputy Head, Tbilisi Prime, December 20, 2003.
scite2: Shots Fired at Home of Prominent Georgian Politician, Associated Press Worldstream, December 20, 2003.

summary: 12/22/2003: Seven unknown assailants wearing ski masks, kidnapped, beat, threatened and after three hours released, political activist, Levan Kacharava, near his home in Batumi, Georgia. The kidnappers threatened Kacharava to discontinue his political activities as an opposition leader to the established government.
target1: Chairman of the Batumi Public Association Levan Kacharava
motive: The specific motive of the attack was to intimidate political opposition to an established order.
scite1: Georgia: Election Activist Abducted, Beaten in Ajaria, Tbilisi Imedi TV, December 22, 2003.
scite2: Georgia: Ajarian Doctors Refuse to See Beaten Activist, BBC Worldwide Monitoring, December 23, 2003
scite3: Georgia: UK Ambassador Upset by Treatment of Election Activist in Ajaria, BBC Monitoring International Reports, December 22, 2003.

summary: 04/04/2004: A bomb exploded in Tbilisi, Georgia, in an attempted assassination of a Russian General, Alexander Studenikin. The bomb, detonated outside of the General's car on his way home from work, was most likely made of TNT. No one was killed in the blast and the General was only slightly injured. No group claimed responsibility for the explosion.
weapdetail: Police believed that the bomb was made of TNT.
scite1: "Georgian Prosecutor Says No One Injured in Attack on Russian General," Moscow Interfax, April 6, 2004.
scite2: "Georgia services investigating bomb attack on Russian," Bahrain News Agency, April 7, 2004.
scite3: "Russian military chief in Georgia lightly wounded in bomb blast," Agence France Presse, April 6, 2004.

location: This incident occurred near the village of Sarabuk.
summary: 08/03/2004: A Russian delegation, led by the head of the Duma CIS affairs committee Andrei Kokoshin, came under intensive rifle fire while driving through the Georgian-Ossetian conflict zone near the village of Sarabuk. No one was injured in the attack, and it was unknown who perpetrated the attack.
